response.name: Create a new image
response.body:
{
    "source": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Pablo_picasso_1.jpg/200px-Pablo_picasso_1.jpg",
    "altText": "Pablo-Picassoo.jpg",
    "height": 300,
    "width": 300,
    "artwork": {
        "id": 64,
        "name": "La Femme qui pleure",
        "year": 1837,
        "description": "The Weeping Woman, I is an elaboration of one of the central figures in Picasso’s famous mural-size painting Guernica, executed some months earlier.",
        "type": "Painting"
    },
    "id": 11
}

response.name: Get all artworks
response.body:
[
    {
        "id": 100,
        "name": "Dogs",
        "year": 1975,
        "description": "Brett Whiteley felt deeply connected to animals since childhood. In fact, between 1965 and 1988 he staged four exhibitions whose predominant or exclusive subject was animals that he had observed in zoos, domestic environments and in nature.",
        "type": "Painting",
        "mainImage": "https://www.bendigoregion.com.au/sites/default/files/2021-05/brett_whiteley_greg_dogs.jpg",
        "images": [
            {
                "id": 100,
                "source": "https://www.bendigoregion.com.au/sites/default/files/2021-05/brett_whiteley_greg_dogs.jpg",
                "altText": "Dogs (1)",
                "height": 889,
                "width": 1296
            },
            {
                "id": 101,
                "source": "shorturl.at/ijzDK",
                "altText": "Dogs (2)",
                "height": 509,
                "width": 742
            }
        ],
        "artist": {
            "id": 100,
            "name": "Brett Whiteley",
            "birthplace": "Sydney, New South Wales, Australia",
            "birthdate": "1939-04-07T05:00:00.000Z",
            "image": "https://content.api.news/v3/images/bin/6e366e88e44b0777b55a87ea6f2ffbd3"
        }
    },
    {
        "id": 101,
        "name": "Self portrait in the studio",
        "year": 1976,
        "description": "Similar to Brett Whiteley's other major paintings of this period, 'Self-portrait in the studio' exudes a sense of sumptuous living and the liquid presence of the harbour through what he called 'the ecstasy-like effect of Ultramarine blue'. Whiteley's tiny mirror self-portrait also reflects the influence of Eastern art in his portrayal of man as merely part of a larger landscape.",
        "type": "Painting",
        "mainImage": "https://www.bendigoregion.com.au/sites/default/files/2021-05/brett_whiteley_greg_self.jpg",
        "images": [
            {
                "id": 102,
                "source": "https://www.bendigoregion.com.au/sites/default/files/2021-05/brett_whiteley_greg_self.jpg",
                "altText": "Self portrait in the studio (1)",
                "height": 961,
                "width": 1229
            },
            {
                "id": 103,
                "source": "http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-us2UwO9e6wY/UZeWyY-AnzI/AAAAAAAAQbc/Fic2bNnJK-4/s640/Whiteley,+Brett,+Self-portrait+in+studio+1975-76.jpg",
                "altText": "Self portrait in the studio (2)",
                "height": 265,
                "width": 505
            }
        ],
        "artist": {
            "id": 100,
            "name": "Brett Whiteley",
            "birthplace": "Sydney, New South Wales, Australia",
            "birthdate": "1939-04-07T05:00:00.000Z",
            "image": "https://content.api.news/v3/images/bin/6e366e88e44b0777b55a87ea6f2ffbd3"
        }
    },
    {
        "id": 102,
        "name": "Self portrait",
        "year": 1931,
        "description": "Painted in 1948, Cossington Smith's self-portrait represents her vibrant use of light-infused colour and interest in structure and form. Depicting herself in the prime of her long career, the short brushstrokes, laden with paint, build up a strong colour portrait and capture the dedication she felt towards her art in her intense focused gaze and the determined set of her lips.",
        "type": "Painting",
        "mainImage": "https://www.portrait.gov.au/files/b/b/2/c/i5398.jpg",
        "images": [
            {
                "id": 104,
                "source": "https://www.portrait.gov.au/files/b/b/2/c/i5398.jpg",
                "altText": "Self portrait (1)",
                "height": 961,
                "width": 744
            },
            {
                "id": 105,
                "source": "https://www.portrait.gov.au/files/b/b/2/c/i5398-trs.jpg",
                "altText": "Self portrait (2)",
                "height": 417,
                "width": 742
            }
        ],
        "artist": {
            "id": 101,
            "name": "Grace Cossington Smith",
            "birthplace": "Neutral Bay, New South Wales, Australia",
            "birthdate": "1892-04-20T04:56:16.000Z",
            "image": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3c/Grace_Cossington_Smith_Turramurra.jpg"
        }
    },
    {
        "id": 103,
        "name": "Connaissance du monde",
        "year": 1996,
        "description": "In the late 1970s, after decades of making handwritten manuscripts, Bouabré began to draw on found cardboard, combining image and text. From the 1980s onwards, as the scope of his interests grew, he embarked on an all-encompassing project, drawing from observation almost daily. He titled the open-ended series of drawings Connaissance du Monde, and worked on it until his death in 2014, systematically compiling and classifying forms, ideas, and a wide range of phenomena, including domestic objects, cloud formations, and tribal scarifications, as well as the political climate and world events.",
        "type": "Painting",
        "mainImage": "https://universes.art/fileadmin/_processed_/2/b/csm_14_ivory_coast_16b2369926.jpg",
        "images": [
            {
                "id": 106,
                "source": "https://universes.art/fileadmin/_processed_/2/b/csm_14_ivory_coast_16b2369926.jpg",
                "altText": "Connaissance du Monde (1)",
                "height": 400,
                "width": 585
            },
            {
                "id": 107,
                "source": "https://www.artmajeur.com/medias/standard/f/r/frederic-bruly-bouabre/artwork/12692411_981f68a5-6473-48dc-8efb-8a3c03a287e6.jpg",
                "altText": "Connaissance du Monde (2)",
                "height": 649,
                "width": 525
            }
        ],
        "artist": {
            "id": 102,
            "name": "Frédéric Bruly Bouabré",
            "birthplace": "Zépréguhé, Côte d'Ivoire",
            "birthdate": "1923-03-11T05:00:00.000Z",
            "image": "https://elhombrejazmin.com/wp-content/imagenes/2013/11/frederic_bruly_bouabre.jpg"
        }
    },
    {
        "id": 104,
        "name": "Thirty Pieces of Silver",
        "year": 1989,
        "description": "Thirty Pieces of Silver comprises over a thousand flattened silver objects, including plates, spoons, candlesticks, trophies, cigarette cases, teapots and trombones. All the objects were ceremoniously crushed by a steamroller at Cornelia Parker's request. She then arranged the transformed silver artefacts into thirty disc-shaped groups, which are suspended about a foot from the floor by hundreds of fine wires. Each 'disc' is approximately ninety centimetres in diameter and they are always hung in orderly rows, although their overall configuration is adapted each time to the space in which the work is displayed. The title refers to the biblical story of how the apostle Judas Iscariot betrayed Jesus in return for thirty pieces of silver.",
        "type": "Object",
        "mainImage": "https://www.tate.org.uk/art/images/work/T/T07/T07461_10.jpg",
        "images": [
            {
                "id": 108,
                "source": "https://www.tate.org.uk/art/images/work/T/T07/T07461_10.jpg",
                "altText": "Thirty Pieces of Silver (1)",
                "height": 611,
                "width": 742
            },
            {
                "id": 109,
                "source": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b4/Thirty_Pieces_of_Silver.jpg",
                "altText": "Thirty Pieces of Silver (2)",
                "height": 556,
                "width": 742
            }
        ],
        "artist": {
            "id": 103,
            "name": "Cornelia Parker",
            "birthplace": "Cheshire, England",
            "birthdate": "1956-07-14T05:00:00.000Z",
            "image": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/28/Cornelia-Parker-010-1.jpg"
        }
    },
    {
        "id": 105,
        "name": "Cold Dark Matter: An Exploded View",
        "year": 1991,
        "description": "Cold Dark Matter: An Exploded View is the restored contents of a garden shed exploded by the British Army at the request of the artist Cornelia Parker. The surviving pieces have been used by Parker to create an installation suspended from the ceiling as if held mid-explosion. Lit by a single lightbulb the fragments cast dramatic shadows on the gallery's walls.",
        "type": "Object",
        "mainImage": "https://media.tate.org.uk/aztate-prd-ew-dg-wgtail-st1-ctr-data/images/.width-1200_LwsaUXy.jpg",
        "images": [
            {
                "id": 110,
                "source": "https://media.tate.org.uk/aztate-prd-ew-dg-wgtail-st1-ctr-data/images/.width-1200_LwsaUXy.jpg",
                "altText": "Cold Dark Matter: An Exploded View (1)",
                "height": 649,
                "width": 511
            },
            {
                "id": 111,
                "source": "https://chisenhale.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/Cold-Dark-Matter-an-Exploded-View_crop-1361x1080.jpg",
                "altText": "Cold Dark Matter: An Exploded View (2)",
                "height": 588,
                "width": 742
            }
        ],
        "artist": {
            "id": 103,
            "name": "Cornelia Parker",
            "birthplace": "Cheshire, England",
            "birthdate": "1956-07-14T05:00:00.000Z",
            "image": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/28/Cornelia-Parker-010-1.jpg"
        }
    },
    {
        "id": 106,
        "name": "Mont Sainte-Victoire seen from Bellevue",
        "year": 1887,
        "description": "Mont Sainte-Victoire seen from Bellevue, 1885-87 is another panoramic view, of a delicate, tranquil beauty. Admirable is the thought of opposing to the distant landscape the high tree in the foreground, a form through which the near and far, the left and right, become more sharply defined, each with its own mood and dominant. Breadth, height, and depth are almost equally developed; the balance of these dimensions is one of the sources of the fullness and calm of the painting. We experience the vastness of the space in the broad valley with the viaduct; we feel the equivalent depth in the long, endless passage from the house in the foreground to the mountain top; but we also measure the great height of the space in the central tree which spans the whole vertical dimension, crossing every zone of the landscape and reaching from the lower to the upper edge of the canvas.",
        "type": "Painting",
        "mainImage": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/30/Paul_Cezanne_La_Montagne_Saint_Victoire_Barnes.jpg",
        "images": [
            {
                "id": 112,
                "source": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/30/Paul_Cezanne_La_Montagne_Saint_Victoire_Barnes.jpg",
                "altText": "Mont Sainte-Victoire seen from Bellevue (1)",
                "height": 588,
                "width": 742
            },
            {
                "id": 113,
                "source": "https://www.phaidon.com/resource/cazannemont1.jpg",
                "altText": "Mont Sainte-Victoire seen from Bellevue (2)",
                "height": 498,
                "width": 620
            }
        ],
        "artist": {
            "id": 104,
            "name": "Paul Cézanne",
            "birthplace": "Aix-en-Provence, France",
            "birthdate": "1839-01-19T04:56:16.000Z",
            "image": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Paul-Cezanne.jpg/220px-Paul-Cezanne.jpg"
        }
    },
    {
        "id": 107,
        "name": "The Large Bathers",
        "year": 1906,
        "description": "The bathers theme originated in the Renaissance and traditionally showed idealized female bodies in total harmony with nature. Yet Cézanne disturbs this easy relationship here and in his other works on the subject. In this canvas, thick with paint, space is hard to read, and the landscape —note the dead tree branches and ominous clouds—seems harsh and threatening. While he derived many of the figures' poses from classical statuary, Cézanne overturns tradition as soon as he references it: bodies are deliberately distorted, with obliterated faces, truncated limbs, and uneven flesh.",
        "type": "Painting",
        "mainImage": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/8ilh53BJ3qY/maxresdefault.jpg",
        "images": [
            {
                "id": 114,
                "source": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/8ilh53BJ3qY/maxresdefault.jpg",
                "altText": "The Large Bathers (1)",
                "height": 417,
                "width": 742
            },
            {
                "id": 115,
                "source": "https://www.reprodart.com/kunst/paul_cezanne/the-large-bathers.jpg",
                "altText": "The Large Bathers (2)",
                "height": 501,
                "width": 600
            }
        ],
        "artist": {
            "id": 104,
            "name": "Paul Cézanne",
            "birthplace": "Aix-en-Provence, France",
            "birthdate": "1839-01-19T04:56:16.000Z",
            "image": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Paul-Cezanne.jpg/220px-Paul-Cezanne.jpg"
        }
    },
    {
        "id": 108,
        "name": "L'Arlésienne",
        "year": 1889,
        "description": "While in Arles, Van Gogh painted two very similar portraits of Marie Ginoux, the proprietress of the Café de la Gare, wearing the regional costume of the legendary dark-haired beauties of Arles. The first version, which he described in a letter of November 1888 as \"an Arlésienne . . . knocked off in one hour,\" must be the more thinly and summarily executed portrait in the Musée d'Orsay, Paris. In it a parasol and gloves lie on the table instead of books. This portrait belonged to the sitter until she sold it in 1895.",
        "type": "Painting",
        "mainImage": "https://collectionapi.metmuseum.org/api/collection/v1/iiif/436529/795979/main-image",
        "images": [
            {
                "id": 116,
                "source": "https://collectionapi.metmuseum.org/api/collection/v1/iiif/436529/795979/main-image",
                "altText": "L'Arlésienne (1)",
                "height": 649,
                "width": 515
            },
            {
                "id": 117,
                "source": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/LArlesienneWithBooks.jpg/300px-LArlesienneWithBooks.jpg",
                "altText": "L'Arlésienne (2)",
                "height": 383,
                "width": 300
            }
        ],
        "artist": {
            "id": 105,
            "name": "Vincent van Gogh",
            "birthplace": "Zundert, Netherlands",
            "birthdate": "1853-03-30T04:56:16.000Z",
            "image": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Vincent_van_Gogh_-_Self-Portrait_-_Google_Art_Project_%28454045%29.jpg/474px-Vincent_van_Gogh_-_Self-Portrait_-_Google_Art_Project_%28454045%29.jpg"
        }
    },
    {
        "id": 109,
        "name": "The Mud Bath",
        "year": 1914,
        "description": "Bathing figures were a traditional way of depicting the nude, but here Bomberg brings the subject into the modern era by basing the scene on steam baths used by the local Jewish population near Bomberg's home in east London. Bomberg was closely associated with a group of artists known as the vorticists. Their aim was to create art that expressed the modern world through imagery derived from machines and the urban environment. Here Bomberg reduces the human figure to a series of geometric shapes, a process he described as 'searching for an intenser expression … where I use Naturalistic Form I have stripped it of all irrelevant matter.'",
        "type": "Painting",
        "mainImage": "https://www.tate.org.uk/art/images/work/T/T00/T00656_10.jpg",
        "images": [
            {
                "id": 118,
                "source": "https://www.tate.org.uk/art/images/work/T/T00/T00656_10.jpg",
                "altText": "The Mud Bath (1)",
                "height": 509,
                "width": 742
            },
            {
                "id": 119,
                "source": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/50/Bomberg%2C_The_Mud_Bath.jpg/300px-Bomberg%2C_The_Mud_Bath.jpg",
                "altText": "The Mud Bath (2)",
                "height": 201,
                "width": 300
            }
        ],
        "artist": {
            "id": 106,
            "name": "David Bomberg",
            "birthplace": "Birmingham, England",
            "birthdate": "1890-12-05T04:56:16.000Z",
            "image": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0f/Photo_of_Davis_Bomberg.jpg"
        }
    }
]

        "description": "Cold Dark Matter: An Exploded View is the restored contents of a garden shed exploded by the British Army at the request of the artist Cornelia Parker. The surviving pieces have been used by Parker to create an installation suspended from the ceiling as if held mid-explosion. Lit by a single lightbulb the fragments cast dramatic shadows on the gallery's walls.",
        "type": "Object",
        "mainImage": "https://media.tate.org.uk/aztate-prd-ew-dg-wgtail-st1-ctr-data/images/.width-1200_LwsaUXy.jpg",
        "images": [
            {
                "id": 110,
                "source": "https://media.tate.org.uk/aztate-prd-ew-dg-wgtail-st1-ctr-data/images/.width-1200_LwsaUXy.jpg",
                "altText": "Cold Dark Matter: An Exploded View (1)",
                "height": 649,
                "width": 511
            },
            {
                "id": 111,
                "source": "https://chisenhale.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/Cold-Dark-Matter-an-Exploded-View_crop-1361x1080.jpg",
                "altText": "Cold Dark Matter: An Exploded View (2)",
                "height": 588,
                "width": 742
            }
        ],
        "artist": {
            "id": 103,
            "name": "Cornelia Parker",
            "birthplace": "Cheshire, England",
            "birthdate": "1956-07-14T05:00:00.000Z",
            "image": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/28/Cornelia-Parker-010-1.jpg"
        }
    },
    {
        "id": 106,
        "name": "Mont Sainte-Victoire seen from Bellevue",
        "year": 1887,
        "description": "Mont Sainte-Victoire seen from Bellevue, 1885-87 is another panoramic view, of a delicate, tranquil beauty. Admirable is the thought of opposing to the distant landscape the high tree in the foreground, a form through which the near and far, the left and right, become more sharply defined, each with its own mood and dominant. Breadth, height, and depth are almost equally developed; the balance of these dimensions is one of the sources of the fullness and calm of the painting. We experience the vastness of the space in the broad valley with the viaduct; we feel the equivalent depth in the long, endless passage from the house in the foreground to the mountain top; but we also measure the great height of the space in the central tree which spans the whole vertical dimension, crossing every zone of the landscape and reaching from the lower to the upper edge of the canvas.",
        "type": "Painting",
        "mainImage": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/30/Paul_Cezanne_La_Montagne_Saint_Victoire_Barnes.jpg",
        "images": [
            {
                "id": 112,
                "source": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/30/Paul_Cezanne_La_Montagne_Saint_Victoire_Barnes.jpg",
                "altText": "Mont Sainte-Victoire seen from Bellevue (1)",
                "height": 588,
                "width": 742
            },
            {
                "id": 113,
                "source": "https://www.phaidon.com/resource/cazannemont1.jpg",
                "altText": "Mont Sainte-Victoire seen from Bellevue (2)",
                "height": 498,
                "width": 620
            }
        ],
        "artist": {
            "id": 104,
            "name": "Paul Cézanne",
            "birthplace": "Aix-en-Provence, France",
            "birthdate": "1839-01-19T04:56:16.000Z",
            "image": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Paul-Cezanne.jpg/220px-Paul-Cezanne.jpg"
        }
    },
    {
        "id": 107,
        "name": "The Large Bathers",
        "year": 1906,
        "description": "The bathers theme originated in the Renaissance and traditionally showed idealized female bodies in total harmony with nature. Yet Cézanne disturbs this easy relationship here and in his other works on the subject. In this canvas, thick with paint, space is hard to read, and the landscape —note the dead tree branches and ominous clouds—seems harsh and threatening. While he derived many of the figures' poses from classical statuary, Cézanne overturns tradition as soon as he references it: bodies are deliberately distorted, with obliterated faces, truncated limbs, and uneven flesh.",
        "type": "Painting",
        "mainImage": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/8ilh53BJ3qY/maxresdefault.jpg",
        "images": [
            {
                "id": 114,
                "source": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/8ilh53BJ3qY/maxresdefault.jpg",
                "altText": "The Large Bathers (1)",
                "height": 417,
                "width": 742
            },
            {
                "id": 115,
                "source": "https://www.reprodart.com/kunst/paul_cezanne/the-large-bathers.jpg",
                "altText": "The Large Bathers (2)",
                "height": 501,
                "width": 600
            }
        ],
        "artist": {
            "id": 104,
            "name": "Paul Cézanne",
            "birthplace": "Aix-en-Provence, France",
            "birthdate": "1839-01-19T04:56:16.000Z",
            "image": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Paul-Cezanne.jpg/220px-Paul-Cezanne.jpg"
        }
    },
    {
        "id": 108,
        "name": "L'Arlésienne",
        "year": 1889,
        "description": "While in Arles, Van Gogh painted two very similar portraits of Marie Ginoux, the proprietress of the Café de la Gare, wearing the regional costume of the legendary dark-haired beauties of Arles. The first version, which he described in a letter of November 1888 as \"an Arlésienne . . . knocked off in one hour,\" must be the more thinly and summarily executed portrait in the Musée d'Orsay, Paris. In it a parasol and gloves lie on the table instead of books. This portrait belonged to the sitter until she sold it in 1895.",
        "type": "Painting",
        "mainImage": "https://collectionapi.metmuseum.org/api/collection/v1/iiif/436529/795979/main-image",
        "images": [
            {
                "id": 116,
                "source": "https://collectionapi.metmuseum.org/api/collection/v1/iiif/436529/795979/main-image",
                "altText": "L'Arlésienne (1)",
                "height": 649,
                "width": 515
            },
            {
                "id": 117,
                "source": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/LArlesienneWithBooks.jpg/300px-LArlesienneWithBooks.jpg",
                "altText": "L'Arlésienne (2)",
                "height": 383,
                "width": 300
            }
        ],
        "artist": {
            "id": 105,
            "name": "Vincent van Gogh",
            "birthplace": "Zundert, Netherlands",
            "birthdate": "1853-03-30T04:56:16.000Z",
            "image": "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Vincent_van_Gogh_-_Self-Portrait_-_Google_Art_Project_%28454045%29.jpg/474px-Vincent_van_Gogh_-_Self-Portrait_-_Google_Art_Project_%28454045%29.jpg"
        }
    },
    {
        "id": 109,
        "name": "The Mud Bath",
        "year": 1914,
        "description": "Bathing figures were a traditional way of depicting the nude, but here Bomberg brings the subject into the modern era by basing the scene on steam baths used by the local Jewish population near Bomberg's home in east London. Bomberg was closely associated with a group of artists known as the vorticists. Their aim was to create art that expressed the modern world through imagery derived from machines and the urban environment. Here Bomberg reduces the human figure to a series of geometric shapes, a process he described as 'searching for an intenser expression … where I use Naturalistic Form I have stripped it of all irrelevant matter.'",
        "type": "Painting",
        "mainImage": "https://www.tate.org.uk/art/images/work/T/T00/T00656_10.jpg",
        "images": [

        "id": 64,
        "name": "La Femme qui pleure",
        "year": 1837,
        "description": "The Weeping Woman, I is an elaboration of one of the central figures in Picasso’s famous mural-size painting Guernica, executed some months earlier.",
        "type": "Painting"
    },
    "id": 11
}
